IndiGo announced strongfinancial results for Q4 FY2025 and the full year FY2025.

For the fourth quarter of FY25, net profit surged by 62% year-on-year to ₹3,067 crore.

Annual net profit for FY25 reached ₹7,258 crore, although this represented an 11% decline compared to FY24.

Revenue from operations increased by 17.3% to ₹80,802.9 crore for FY25.

The airline demonstrated improved operational efficiency, with a Passenger Load Factor of 87.4% in Q4 FY25 and increased Available Seat Kilometers (ASKs).

IndiGo also received its first-ever international investment-grade credit rating from Moody's.

IndiGo unveiled ambitious plans toexpand its international network, adding 10 new destinations in FY26.

These new destinations include London and Copenhagen in Europe, Siem Reap in Cambodia, Athens in Greece, and four cities in Central Asia.

The airline aims to increase its global network from 40 to 50 international destinations in a single year.

IndiGo is also focusing onstrengthening domestic connectivityby adding flights and increasing frequencies on key routes, especially from Bengaluru and Hyderabad.

They are deploying additional flights on routes connecting to Tier-2 cities and regional destinations.

A new daily service between Tiruchirappalli and Jaffna will also be introduced.

Despite strong financial and expansion news, IndiGo faced some challenges in May 2025, including:

Flight cancellations due to security concerns related to "Operation Sindoor".

Scrutiny surrounding its wet-lease agreements with Turkish Airlines.

Capacity constraints caused by Pratt & Whitney engine issues, grounding some A320neo aircraft.
